claim: The most expensive color in the world is Blue.

supporting.text: Historically, ultramarine blue pigment was made from lapis lazuli, a rare and expensive gemstone, making it the most expensive color in the past.

attacks.text: Historically, ultramarine blue pigment was made from lapis lazuli, a rare and expensive gemstone, making it the most expensive color in the past.
Modern synthetic ultramarine blue is inexpensive and widely available, making historical rarity irrelevant today.
Other colors, such as certain shades of red derived from cochineal insects, were historically more expensive than ultramarine blue.
Even historically, the cost of ultramarine blue varied significantly based on trade routes and availability, making it not universally the most expensive.
Some historical records indicate that purple dyes, like Tyrian purple, were more expensive than ultramarine blue due to their labor-intensive production.

supporting.text: Synthetic blue pigments like cobalt blue and cerulean blue are costly due to the expensive raw materials and complex manufacturing processes involved.

attacks.text: Synthetic blue pigments like cobalt blue and cerulean blue are costly due to the expensive raw materials and complex manufacturing processes involved.
Natural ultramarine blue, made from lapis lazuli, is historically more expensive than synthetic blue pigments due to its rarity and labor-intensive extraction process.
Modern synthetic pigments like YInMn blue (a vibrant inorganic blue) are even more expensive than cobalt or cerulean blue due to patented production methods and limited availability.
Some non-blue pigments, such as certain shades of red derived from rare minerals or organic compounds, can surpass the cost of even the most expensive blue pigments.
The claim specifies 'color' broadly, not just pigments; Vantablack (a super-black coating) is technically more expensive per gram than any blue pigment due to its unique light-absorption properties.

supporting.text: Other colors, such as certain shades of red derived from crushed cochineal insects or purple from Tyrian dye, have historically been more expensive than blue.

attacks.text: Other colors, such as certain shades of red derived from crushed cochineal insects or purple from Tyrian dye, have historically been more expensive than blue.
Ultramarine blue, made from lapis lazuli, was historically more expensive than cochineal red or Tyrian purple due to the rarity and difficulty of sourcing lapis lazuli.
The cost of Tyrian purple was exorbitant due to the labor-intensive extraction process from thousands of sea snails, making it more expensive than ultramarine blue in certain periods.
Modern synthetic ultramarine blue is inexpensive, whereas natural Tyrian purple remains costly due to its historical production methods.

supporting.text: The cost of a color depends on its application; some blue dyes used in textiles or art may be cheaper than rare pigments used in other colors.

attacks.text: The cost of a color depends on its application; some blue dyes used in textiles or art may be cheaper than rare pigments used in other colors.
Historically, ultramarine blue, made from lapis lazuli, was more expensive than gold due to its rarity and labor-intensive extraction process.
Modern synthetic alternatives like phthalocyanine blue have drastically reduced the cost of blue pigments, making them more affordable than some rare organic pigments.
Even with synthetic alternatives, certain high-purity blue pigments for specialized applications (e.g., aerospace coatings) can still be extremely expensive.

supporting.text: Modern advancements in pigment production have reduced the cost of many historically expensive colors, including blue, making it no longer the most expensive.

attacks.text: Modern advancements in pigment production have reduced the cost of many historically expensive colors, including blue, making it no longer the most expensive.
Certain rare blue pigments, such as Lapis Lazuli or YInMn Blue, remain extremely expensive due to limited natural sources or complex synthesis processes.
Even rare blue pigments are now synthesized at scale, reducing their cost significantly compared to historical prices.
Artisanal and high-end markets still demand naturally sourced blue pigments, maintaining their premium pricing.

supporting.text: The perception of blue as the most expensive color may stem from its historical rarity, but current market prices for pigments do not consistently support this claim.

attacks.text: The perception of blue as the most expensive color may stem from its historical rarity, but current market prices for pigments do not consistently support this claim.
Historically, blue pigments like ultramarine were derived from lapis lazuli, which was more expensive than gold, reinforcing its perception as the most expensive color.
Modern synthetic blue pigments, such as phthalocyanine blue, are mass-produced and inexpensive, undermining the historical rarity argument.
Certain rare blue pigments, like YInMn blue, remain costly due to their unique properties and limited production, supporting the claim in specific contexts.
Other colors, such as certain shades of red derived from rare minerals or organic compounds, can be even more expensive than blue pigments today.
